title: Learning in a World That’s Lost: A Homeschooler’s Perspective

content.text: Let’s be real—our world is kind of a mess. Turn on the news, scroll through social media, or just walk through a crowded mall, and you’ll see it. People chasing after money, fame, and influence. Kids being told they can define truth for themselves. Schools pushing an agenda that leaves God completely out of the picture. As homeschoolers, we’ve been given a unique opportunity—to step outside of that system and learn differently. But that doesn’t mean we’re immune to the influence of a lost world. So, how do we stay strong? How do we learn, grow, and prepare for life while keeping our faith at the center?

One of the biggest challenges in today’s world is that truth is under attack. Society says truth is relative—that whatever feels right must be right. But as Christians, we know that’s not how it works. God’s Word is the foundation of truth, whether people like it or not. The Bible isn’t just a book of nice stories and old-fashioned rules—it’s the ultimate guide for life. And when we keep God’s truth at the core of our education, we’re building on a foundation that won’t crumble when culture shifts.

The world tells us that education is about success—getting good grades, getting into a top college, landing a high-paying job. But what if education is about something deeper? Proverbs 1:7 says, 'The fear of the Lord is the beginning of knowledge.' Real wisdom doesn’t come from textbooks alone—it comes from knowing God. Homeschooling gives us the freedom to learn with purpose. We can study history and see God’s hand at work. We can explore science and marvel at His creation. We can read literature and recognize the battle between good and evil. Learning isn’t just about filling our heads with information—it’s about training our hearts to seek truth.

content.section: Standing Firm in a Shifting Culture
content.text: We live in a world that wants us to blend in, to go with the flow, to accept whatever is 'normal.' But Jesus never called us to be normal. He called us to be set apart. Romans 12:2 reminds us, 'Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind.' That means we can’t just take in everything the world throws at us without filtering it through God’s truth. Whether it’s what we watch, what we listen to, or what we believe about ourselves, we need to ask: 'Does this line up with what God says?' Because if it doesn’t, we need to be willing to let it go.

content.section: Using Our Education for God's Glory
content.text: At the end of the day, education isn’t just about us. It’s about how we can use what we learn to serve God and impact the world around us. Maybe you love writing—how can you use that to share truth? Maybe you’re into science—how can you use that to point people to the Creator? Maybe you’re gifted in music—how can you use that to glorify God? Every skill, every talent, every subject we study can be used for His kingdom. The goal isn’t just to be smart—it’s to be faithful.

We live in a world that’s lost, but we don’t have to be lost with it. We’ve been given the gift of an education that allows us to learn through the lens of truth. So let’s not waste it. Let’s seek wisdom, stand firm, and use our learning to shine a light in the darkness. Because in the end, it’s not just about what we know—it’s about who we serve.
